newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: Spain's debt market ended higher on Wednesday drawing support from the European commission forecast saying that Spain's 1997 deficit to gross domestic product ratio would be at 3.0 percent.

"Everything hinting Spain will be part of European Monetary Union for the outset brings a lowered spread and yields," a money market dealer in Madrid said. "The good news is Spain will meet the criteria. The bad news is that Italy will not."
But after having declined in anticipation, the Italian market also recovered in the afternoon on the news.
As the lira also recouped initial losses, the peseta ended stronger trading at around 84.31/33 per mark. Dealers said that the currency recovery was also pulling bonos higher.
"A firmer peseta is the best insurance for the bond market," an analyst said.
On the short end of the yield curve, dealers started to anticipate a new possible official rate cut by mid-May.
Analysts are expecting that April's consumer price index could show a yearly rise breaking the two percent level from 2.2 percent in March.
